clinical_study.brief_title: Remimazolam and Remifentanil Without Neuromuscular Blocking Agent
clinical_study.official_title: General Anesthesia Using Remimazolam and Remifentanil Without Neuromuscular Blocking Agent: Prospective Observational Study

brief_summary.textblock: Remimazolam is a novel drug approved for induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. This study aims to check the appropriate dose and patient response by administering remimazolam and remifentanil in surgery that does not require a neuromuscular blocking agents.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During the anesthesia induction (from initiation of anesthesia until the insertion of laryngeal mask airway)
During the anesthesia maintenance (from the insertion of laryngeal mask airway until stopping remimazolam infusion)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the anesthesia (from initiation of anesthesia until stopping remimazolam infusion)
During the anesthesia (from initiation of anesthesia until stopping remimazolam infusion)
During the anesthesia recovery (from stopping remimazolam infusion until the recovery of consciousness)

intervention.description: Loading for anesthesia induction: Remimazolam 12 mg/kg/h until loss of consciousness Continuous infusion for anesthesia maintenance: Remimazolam 1-2 mg/kg/h under the Bispectral index monitoring
intervention.arm_group_label: General anesthesia using remimazolam and remifentanil

study_pop.textblock: Adult woman scheduled for gynecological surgery under general anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult woman scheduled for gynecological surgery under general anesthesia
- American Society of Anesthesiology grade 1 or 2
- When using a laryngeal mask airway to maintain general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Underlying diseases: liver, kidney, brain nervous system, glaucoma
- Patients with BMI greater than 30 and less than 18.5
- Patients diagnosed with sleep apnea
- Alcohol or drug dependent patients
- Patients with severe or acute respiratory failure
- Lactose intolerance
- Dextran 40 hypersensitivity
- Patients in shock or coma
